verses.story_title: The story of the monk Cakkhupāla

text.pali: Manopubbaṅgamā dhammā, manoseṭṭhā manomayā; manasā ce paduṭṭhena, bhāsati vā karoti vā. Tato naṃ dukkhamanveti, cakkaṃva vahato padaṃ.
text.en_translator_a: All mental phenomena have mind as their forerunner; they have the mind as their chief; they are mind-made. If one speaks or acts with an evil mind, 'dukkha' 3 follows him just as the wheel follows the hoofprint of the ox that draws the cart.

text.pali: Manopubbaṅgamā dhammā, manoseṭṭhā manomayā; manasā ce pasannena, bhāsati vā karoti vā. Tato naṃ sukhamanveti, chāyāva anapāyinī.
text.en_translator_a: All mental phenomena have mind as their forerunner; they have mind as their chief; they are mind-made. If one speaks or acts with a pure mind, happiness (sukha) follows him like a shadow that never leaves him.

text.pali: Akkocchi maṃ avadhi maṃ, ajini maṃ ahāsi me; ye ca taṃ upanayhanti, veraṃ tesaṃ na sammati.
text.en_translator_a: “He abused me, he ill-treated me, he got the better of me, he stole my belongings” — the enmity of those harbouring such thoughts cannot be appeased.

text.pali: Akkocchi maṃ avadhi maṃ, ajini maṃ ahāsi me; ye ca taṃ nupanayhanti, veraṃ tesūpasammati.
text.en_translator_a: “He abused me, he struck me, he overpowered me, he robbed me” — those who do not harbor such thoughts still their hatred.

text.pali: Na hi verena verāni, sammantīdha kudācanaṃ; averena ca sammanti, esa dhammo sanantano.
text.en_translator_a: Hatred is, indeed, never appeased by hatred in this world. It is appeased only by loving-kindness. This is an eternal law.

text.pali: Pare ca na vijānanti, mayamettha yamāmase; ye ca tattha vijānanti, tato sammanti medhagā.
text.en_translator_a: People, other than the wise, do not realize, "We in this world must all die," (and, not realizing it, continue their quarrels). The wise realize it and thereby their quarrels cease.

text.pali:
Subhanupassim viharantam
indriyesu asamvutam
bhojanamhi camattannum
kusitam hinaviriyam
tam ve pasahati Maro
vato rukkhamva dubbalam.
text.en_translator_a: The good person who is mindful, restrained in the senses, moderate in eating, and diligent in effort, him Mara (the Evil One) cannot overpower, just as the wind cannot uproot a mountain.

text.pali:
Asubhanupassim viharantam
indriyesu susamvutam
bhojanamhi ca mattannum
saddham2 araddhaviriyam
tam ve nappasahati Maro
vato selamva pabbatam.
text.en_translator_a: He who keeps his mind on the impurities (of the body), who is well-controlled in his senses and is full of faith and energy, will certainly be not overwhelmed by Mara, just as stormy winds cannot shake a mountain of rock.

text.pali:
Anikkasavo kasavam
yo vattham paridahissati
apeto damasaccena
na so kasavamarahati.
text.en_translator_a: He who is not free from taints of moral defilements (kilesas) and yet dons the yellow robe, who lacks restraint in his senses and (speaks not the) truth is unworthy of the yellow robe.

text.pali:
Yo ca vantakasav'assa
silesu susamahito
upeto damasaccena
sa ve kasavamarahati.
text.en_translator_a: He who is free from taints of moral defilements (kilesas) and is well-restrained in his senses, who is full of faith and energy, he is indeed worthy of the yellow robe.

text.pali:
Asaresaramatino
sarecasaradassino
te saram nadhigacchanti
micchasankappagocara.
text.en_translator_a: They take untruth for truth; they take truth for untruth; such persons can never arrive at the truth, for they hold wrong views.

text.pali:
Saranca sarato natva
asaranca adhigacchanti
te saram adhigacchanti
sammasankappagocara.
text.en_translator_a: They take the truth for the truth; they take the untruth for the untruth; such persons can arrive at the truth, for they hold right views.

text.pali:
Yatha agaram ducchannam
vutthi samativijjhati
evam abhavitam cittam
rago samativijjhati.
text.en_translator_a: Just as rain penetrates a badly-roofed house, so also, passion (raga) penetrates a mind not cultivated in Tranquillity and Insight Development (Samatha and Vipassana).

text.pali:
Yatha agaram suchannam
vutthi na samativijjhati
evam subhavitam cittam
rago na samativijjhati.
text.en_translator_a: Just as rain cannot penetrate a well-roofed house, so also, passion (raga) cannot penetrate a mind well-cultivated in Tranquillity and Insight Development (Samatha and Vipassa).

text.pali:
Idha socati pecca socati
papakari ubhayattha socati
so socati so vihannati
disva kammakilitthamattano.
text.en_translator_a: Here he grieves, hereafter he grieves; the evil-doer grieves in both existences. He grieves and he suffers anguish when he sees the depravity of his own deeds.

text.pali:
Idha modati pecca modati
katapunno ubhayattha modati
so modati so pamodati
disva kammavisuddhimattano.
text.en_translator_a: Here he rejoices, hereafter he rejoices; one who performed meritorious deeds rejoices in both existences. He rejoices and greatly rejoices when he sees the purity of his own deeds.

text.pali:
Idha tappati pecca tappati
papakari ubhayattha tappati
papam me katanti tappati
bhiyyo tappati duggatim gato.
text.en_translator_a: Here he is tormented, hereafter he is tormented; the evil-doer is tormented in both existences. He is tormented, and he laments: "Evil have I done." He is even more tormented when he is reborn in one of the lower worlds (Apaya).

text.pali:
Idha nandati pecca nandati
katapunno ubhayattha nandati
punnam me katanti nandati
bhiyyo nandati suggatim gato.
text.en_translator_a: Here he is happy, hereafter he is happy; one who performs meritorious deeds is happy in both existences. Happily he exclaims: I have done meritorious deeds." He is happier still when he is reborn in a higher world (suggati).

text.pali:
Bahumpi ce samhita bhasamano
na takkaro hoti naro pamatto
gopova gavo ganayam paresam
na bhagava samannassa hoti.
text.en_translator_a: Though he recites much the Sacred Texts (Tipitaka), but is negligent and does not practise according to the Dhamma, like a cowherd who counts the cattle of others, he has no share in the benefits of the life of a bhikkhu (i.e., Magga-phala).

text.pali:
Appampi ce samhita bhasamano
dhammassa hoti anudhammacari
raganca dosanca pahaya moham
sammappajano suvimuttacitto
anupadiyano idha va haram va
sa bhagava samannassa hoti.
text.en_translator_a: Though he recites only a little of the Sacred Texts (Tipitaka), but practises according to the Dhamma, eradicating passion, ill will and ignorance, clearly comprehending the Dhamma, with his mind freed from moral defilements and no longer clinging to this world or to the next, he shares the benefits of the life of a bhikkhu (i.e., Magga-phala).

text.pali: Appamādo amatapadaṁ, pamādo maccuno padaṁ; Appamattā na mīyanti, ye pamattā yathā matā.
text.en_translator_a: Appamada is the Path to the Deathless, heedlessness the Path to Death. Those who are heedful do not die; the heedless are as if dead already.

text.pali: Etaṁ visesato ñatvā, appamādamhi paṇḍitā; Appamāde pamodanti, ariyānaṁ gocare ratā.
text.en_translator_a: Having understood this clearly, the wise rejoice in heedfulness, delighting in the domain of the Noble Ones.

text.pali: Te jhāyino sātatikā, niccaṁ daḷhaparakkamā; Phusanti dhīrā nibbānaṁ, yogakkhemaṁ anuttaraṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The constant meditators, persevering, constantly firm in effort, attain Nibbana, the supreme peace from the bonds.

verses.story_title: The Story of Kumbhaghosaka, the Banker

text.pali: Uṭṭhānavato satīmato, sucikammassa nisammakārino; Saññatassa dhammajīvino, appamattassa yaso’bhivaḍḍhati.
text.en_translator_a: By effort, by heedfulness, by restraint and self-control, the wise man can make for himself an island which no flood can overwhelm.

text.pali: Uṭṭhānen'appamādena, saññamena damena ca; Dīpaṁ kayirātha medhāvī, yaṁ ogho nābhikīrati.
text.en_translator_a: Youth is like spring, man's age like autumn; but spring is short, autumn is long. Therefore the wise should do good deeds in youth.

verses.story_title: The Story of Bāla Nakkhatta Festival

text.pali: Pamāde viharanti bālā, pāmojjabahulā narā; Appamādamhi paṇḍitā, sukhaṁ gacchanti āsīdā.
text.en_translator_a: Let the fool indulge in heedlessness; the wise man should be heedful. The fool will regret his heedlessness; the wise man rejoices in heedfulness.

verses.story_title: The Story of Bāla Nakkhatta Festival

text.pali: Na hi pamodo hoti ñātī, pamattā hi naṃ paṭibhāti; Appamattā ca medhāvī, pamādaṁ daḷham aṭṭhiti.
text.en_translator_a: Do not associate with heedless people, nor with those who indulge in heedlessness. Associate with the heedful, the wise.

text.pali: Appamādo amatapadaṁ, pamādo maccuno padaṁ; Appamattā na mīyanti, ye pamattā yathā matā.
text.en_translator_a: As the lily blooms in the mud, so the wise man blooms among the heedless.

verses.story_title: The Story of the Two Companion Monks

text.pali: Tasmā hi attadāḷhassa, appamādo sukhaṁ sadā; Sukhaṁ appamattānassa, sabbattha appamādinā.
text.en_translator_a: The wise man, self-reliant, looks to the end of the journey.

text.pali: Appamattā sukhassāsi, pamattā dukkhabhaginī; Pamattesu bhayāni passati, appamattā sukhena yojayati.
text.en_translator_a: The heedful are happy, the heedless are in misery. The heedful man sees danger in heedlessness, the heedless man does not see the danger in heedlessness.

verses.story_title: The Story of a Certain Monk

text.pali: Appamādo amatarūpaṁ, pamādo maccunā saha; Ve jānantā appamāde, appamādena muccare.
text.en_translator_a: Do not call him a sage who does not understand the Way. He is a sage who understands the Way and who practices it.

verses.story_title: The Story of Monk Nigāma Vāsi Tissa

text.pali: Appamattā sukhaṁ labhanti, pamattā dukkhaṁ labhanti; Appamattā sukhā lokā, pamattā dukkhā lokā.
text.en_translator_a: The wise man delights in the Dhamma, the wise man delights in the Sangha. The wise man delights in the destruction of craving.

text.pali: Phandanaṁ capalaṁ cittaṁ, dūrakkhaṁ dunnivārayaṁ; Ujuṁ karoti medhāvī, usukāro'va tejanaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The mind is difficult to check, swift, flits wherever it listeth. The control of the mind is good. A controlled mind is conducive to happiness.

text.pali: Vārijo va thale khitto, okamokata ubbhato; Pariphandat’idaṁ cittaṁ, māradheyyaṁ pahātave.
text.en_translator_a: The mind is very hard to perceive, extremely subtle, flits wherever it listeth. Let the wise man guard the mind, a guarded mind is conducive to happiness.

verses.story_title: The Story of a Certain Monk

text.pali: Dunniggahassa lahuno, yatthakāmanipātino; Cittassa damatho sādhu, cittaṁ dantaṁ sukhāvahaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The mind wanders far, wanders alone, is formless, stands aloof. Let him bring the mind back, let him restrain the mind. Let the wise man make his mind as a light, let him guard the mind, let him forsake evil.

verses.story_title: The Story of a Certain Disgruntled Monk

text.pali: Sududdasaṁ sunipuṇaṁ, yatthakāmanipātinaṁ; Cittaṁ rakkhetha medhāvī, cittaṁ guttaṁ sukhāvahaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: Like a fletcher makes straight his arrow, a wise man makes straight his trembling and unsteady thought, which is difficult to guard, difficult to restrain.

text.pali: Dūraṅgamaṁ ekacaraṁ, asarīraṁ guhāsayaṁ; Ye cittaṁ saññamessanti, mokkhanti mārabandhanā.
text.en_translator_a: As a fish, taken from his watery home and thrown on dry ground, our thought flutters, O men! The thought is hard to restrain, the thought is difficult to hold.

text.pali: Anavaṭṭhitacittassa, saddhammaṁ avijānato; Pariplavapasādassa, paññā na paripūrati.
text.en_translator_a: The mind is restless, not long abiding, hard to control, very strong. Let the wise man subdue the mind, let him forsake the evil thought.

text.pali: Anavassutacittassa, ananvāhatacetaso; Puññapāpahīnassa, natthi jāgarato bhayaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: This mind of ours is difficult to restrain, sudden, unruly, and always looking for its own gratification. To train it is good.

verses.story_title: The Story of Five Hundred Monks

text.pali: Kumbhūpamaṁ kāyam imaṁ viditvā, nagarūpamaṁ cittam idaṁ ṭhapetvā; Yodhetha māraṁ paññāvudhena, jitaṁ ca rakkhe anivesano siyā.
text.en_translator_a: The mind is hard to check, swift, flits wherever it listeth. The control of the mind is good. A controlled mind is conducive to happiness.

verses.story_title: The Story of Tissa, the Monk with a Stinking Body

text.pali: Aciraṁ vat’ayaṁ kāyo, pathaviṁ adhisessati; Chuddho apetasañño, niratthaṁ va kaliṅgaraṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The mind is very hard to perceive, extremely subtle, flits wherever it listeth. Let the wise man guard the mind, a guarded mind is conducive to happiness.

verses.story_title: The Story of Nanda, the Herdsman

text.pali: Diso disaṁ yaṁ taṁ kayirā, verī vā pana verinaṁ; Micchāpaṇihitaṁ cittaṁ, pāpiyo naṁ tato kare.
text.en_translator_a: The mind wanders far, wanders alone, is formless, stands aloof. Let him bring the mind back, let him restrain the mind. Let the wise man make his mind as a light, let him guard the mind, let him forsake evil.

text.pali: Na taṁ mātā pitā kayirā, aññe vā pana ñātakā; Sammāpaṇihitaṁ cittaṁ, seyyaso naṁ tato kare.
text.en_translator_a: Like a fletcher makes straight his arrow, a wise man makes straight his trembling and unsteady thought, which is difficult to guard, difficult to restrain.

verses.story_title: The Story of Five Hundred Monks

text.pali: Ko imaṁ pathaviṁ vicessati, yamalokañ ca imaṁ sadevakaṁ; Ko dhammapadaṁ sudesitaṁ, kusalo puppham ivappacessati.
text.en_translator_a: Who shall overcome this earth, and the world of Yama with its gods? Who shall find the well-taught Dhammapada as a skilled man finds the flower?

verses.story_title: The Story of Five Hundred Monks

text.pali: Sekho pathaviṁ vicessati, yamalokañ ca imaṁ sadevakaṁ; Sekho dhammapadaṁ sudesitaṁ, kusalo puppham ivappacessati.
text.en_translator_a: The disciple shall overcome this earth, and the world of Yama with its gods. The disciple shall find the well-taught Dhammapada as a skilled man finds the flower.

verses.story_title: The Story of the Monk who Contemplates The Body as a Mirage

text.pali: Pheṇūpamaṁ kāyam imaṁ viditvā, marīcidhammaṁ abhisambudhāno; Chetvā mārassa papupphakāni, adassanaṁ maccurājassa gacche.
text.en_translator_a: Knowing that the body is like foam, realizing the impermanence of this body, breaking Māra's flower-arrows, he goes beyond the sight of the King of Death.

text.pali: Pupphāni h’eva pacinantaṁ, byāsattamanasaṁ naraṁ; Suttaṁ gāmaṁ mahogho’va, maccu ādāya gacchati.
text.en_translator_a: He who plucks flowers, whose mind is distracted, death carries him away as a flood carries away a sleeping village.

text.pali: Pupphāni h’eva pacinantaṁ, byāsattamanasaṁ naraṁ; Atittaṁ yeva kāmesu, antakā so upaddave.
text.en_translator_a: The destroyer brings under his sway the person who plucks flowers, whose mind is distracted, and whose appetite for sense-pleasures is insatiable.

verses.story_title: The Story of Kosiya, the Miserly Rich Man

text.pali: Yathā pi bhamaro pupphaṁ, vaṇṇagandha aheṭhayaṁ; Paḷeti rasam ādāya, evaṁ gāme muni care.
text.en_translator_a: As a bee gathers nectar from the flower without injuring its color or fragrance, so should the sage go about a village.

verses.story_title: The Story of the Ascetic Pāveyya

text.pali: Na pare saṁ vilomāni, na pare saṁ katākataṁ; Attano va avekkheyya, katāni akatāni ca.
text.en_translator_a: Do not look for faults in others, nor consider what others have done or not done. Look at what you have done and not done.

text.pali: Yathā pi ruciraṁ pupphaṁ, vaṇṇavantaṁ agandhakaṁ; Evaṁ subhāsitā vācā, aphalaṁ hoti akubbato.
text.en_translator_a: As a beautiful flower, full of color but without scent, even so fruitless is the well-spoken word of one who does not practice it.

text.pali: Yathā pi ruciraṁ pupphaṁ, vaṇṇavantaṁ sagandhakaṁ; Evaṁ subhāsitā vācā, saphalaṁ hoti kubbato.
text.en_translator_a: As a beautiful flower, full of color and also fragrant, even so fruitful is the well-spoken word of one who practices it.

text.pali: Yathā pi puppharasmiṁ, karote mālguṇe bahū; Evaṁ jātena maccena, kattabbaṁ kusalaṁ bahuṁ.
text.en_translator_a: As from a heap of flowers many garlands can be made, even so should many good things be done by one born a man.

text.pali: Na pupphagandho paṭivātam eti, na candanaṁ tagaramallikā vā; Satañ ca gandho paṭivātam eti, sabbā disā sappuriso pavāti.
text.en_translator_a: The scent of flowers does not travel against the wind, nor even that of sandalwood, tagara, or mallika. The scent of the virtuous does travel against the wind; the virtuous man pervades every direction.

text.pali: Candanaṁ tagaraṁ vā pi, uppalaṁ atha vassikī; Etesaṁ gandhajātānaṁ, sīlagandho anuttaro.
text.en_translator_a: Sandalwood and tagara, lotus and jasmine — among these kinds of fragrance, the fragrance of virtue is supreme.

text.pali: Appamatto ayaṁ gandho, yāyaṁ tagaracandanī; Yo ca sīlavataṁ gandho, vāti devesu uttamo.
text.en_translator_a: Of all fragrances, that of virtue is supreme. Even among the gods, this fragrance of the virtuous is unsurpassed.

text.pali: Tesu ca appamattesu, sampajānasa sīlesu; Vimuttivijjā vimuccati, māradheyyaṁ na vindati.
text.en_translator_a: The fragrance of the virtuous, possessed of moral conduct and heedful, wafts even to the gods. Māra cannot find the path of such steadfast ones.

text.pali: Yathā saṅkāradhānasmiṁ, ujjhitasmiṁ mahāpathe; Padumaṁ tattha jāyetha, sucigandhaṁ manoramaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: As on a heap of rubbish cast upon the highway the lily will grow full of sweet perfume and delight, thus the disciple of the truly enlightened Buddha shines forth by his knowledge among those who are like rubbish, among the people that walk in darkness.

text.pali: Evaṁ saṅkārabhūtesu, andhabhūte puthujjane; Atirocati paññāya, sammāsambuddhasāvako.
text.en_translator_a: As a lily, sweet-scented and beautiful, so the disciple of the Perfectly Enlightened One shines forth by his knowledge among the blind multitude.

text.pali: Dīghā jāgarato ratti, dīghaṁ santassa yojanaṁ; Dīgho bālāna saṁsāro, saddhammaṁ avijānataṁ.
text.en_translator_a: Long is the night to him who is awake; long is a mile to him who is tired; long is life to the foolish who do not know the true law.

text.pali: Yassa jīvitam ratti, yaṁ na jāgati naṃ maccu; Tassa rattiṁ ahārāya, yaṁ na jāgati naṁ maccu.
text.en_translator_a: If a traveller do not meet any one to enter into discourse with, or a wise man, let him hasten alone; there is no companionship with a fool.

text.pali: Ahaṁ bālo, na jānāmi, katvāyaṁ me na sādhu kiṁ; Iti bālo viññāya, bālo hoti tato paraṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The fool who knows his foolishness is wise at least to that extent, but the fool who thinks himself wise is a fool indeed.

text.pali: Yāvajīvampi ce bālo, paṇḍitaṁ paiṭṭhiya seyyo; Na hi tassa paṭirūpaṁ, saṁsaggā atthi kuhiñci.
text.en_translator_a: Though he be a fool, if he consort with a wise man he fares well; but if he be a wise man and consort with a fool he suffers harm.

text.pali: Yadā ca hoti mahādhano, bālo hoti mahāppako; Atha dhīro viññāsi, bālo hoti tato paraṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The fool even when he has wealth has no knowledge of the good, but the wise man, even when poor, has understanding of the good.

text.pali: Ahaṁ bālo, na jānāmi, katvāyaṁ me na sādhu kiṁ; Iti bālo viññāya, bālo hoti tato paraṁ.
text.en_translator_a: Though all his life a fool associate with a wise man, he no more comprehends the Truth than the spoon the flavour of the soup.

text.pali: Yadā ca hoti mahādhano, bālo hoti mahāppako; Atha dhīro viññāsi, bālo hoti tato paraṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The wise man, though but a moment with a wise man associate, quickly comprehends the Truth, as the tongue the flavour of the soup.

text.pali: Attānaṁ upahantvāya, kammaṁ kubbati bālako; Pāpaṁ vata bālo kammaṁ, kubbati na sukhāya te.
text.en_translator_a: Fools of poor understanding, men of scanty knowledge, these fools do evil deeds which bear bitter fruit.

text.pali: Yassa patīto sumano, vipākaṁ paṭisevati; Sukhaṁ vata bālo kammaṁ, kubbati na dukhāya te.
text.en_translator_a: That deed is done, O fool, which thou repentest after it is done, and weepest over, beating thy breast; such evil deed is not done.

text.pali: Yassa patīto sumano, vipākaṁ paṭisevati; Sukhaṁ vata bālo kammaṁ, kubbati na dukhāya te.
text.en_translator_a: But that deed is well done, O fool, which thou doest not repent, after it is done, and of which after thou art glad, and for which thou rejoicest.

text.pali: Madhuṁ vāmaṁ va maññanti, bālā loke manussā te; Piṭṭhaṁ vāmaṁ va maññanti, bālā loke manussā te.
text.en_translator_a: The fool thinks the evil deed as sweet as honey, but he sorrows afterwards, when the evil deed bears fruit.

text.pali: Madhuṁ vāmaṁ va maññanti, bālā loke manussā te; Piṭṭhaṁ vāmaṁ va maññanti, bālā loke manussā te.
text.en_translator_a: The fool thinks the good deed as bitter as poison, but sorrow does not spring up afterwards, when the good deed bears fruit.

text.pali: Abhutvā saddhaṁ kubbati, bhiyyo akusalaṁ pasu; Sukhaṁ vata bālo kammaṁ, kubbati na dukhāya te.
text.en_translator_a: The fool, even if he gain much wealth, enjoys it not; for through his unwise use it is lost, or stolen, or burned.

text.pali: Yassa patīto sumano, vipākaṁ paṭisevati; Sukhaṁ vata bālo kammaṁ, kubbati na dukhāya te.
text.en_translator_a: At the end of life the fool, even if rich, comes empty-handed, like a hunter from the wood, with hands empty.

text.pali: Madhuṁ vāmaṁ va maññanti, bālā loke manussā te; Piṭṭhaṁ vāmaṁ va maññanti, bālā loke manussā te.
text.en_translator_a: The fool even if he have much wealth, enjoys not that wealth; for through his unwise use it is lost, or stolen, or burned.

text.pali: Abhutvā saddhaṁ kubbati, bhiyyo akusalaṁ pasu; Sukhaṁ vata bālo kammaṁ, kubbati na dukhāya te.
text.en_translator_a: At the end of life the fool, even if rich, comes empty-handed, like a hunter from the wood, with hands empty.

text.en_translator_a: All tremble at punishment; all hold their lives dear. Putting oneself in the place of the other, let one neither kill nor cause to kill.

text.en_translator_a: One who, seeking his own happiness, does not oppress with violence other beings who also desire happiness, will find happiness hereafter.

text.en_translator_a: If, having indeed treated others in anger, you now fear retribution, then do not treat others in anger; do not increase the misery of the world.

text.en_translator_a: He who, though angry, restrains his anger as [a skilled charioteer] a king’s speedy horse with a leather strap, him I call a true charioteer; others only hold the reins.

text.en_translator_a: Let him conquer anger by love, let him conquer evil by good; let him conquer the stingy by giving, let him conquer the liar by truth.

text.en_translator_a: Speak the truth, give whatever you can, ne’er be angry with anyone. On the limits of the law, let him restrain his mind wisely.

text.en_translator_a: The mind is unbound, it runs where it will. Let the wise man guard the mind, a guarded mind is conducive to happiness.

text.en_translator_a: The miser sprinkles dust over his head and weeps when he sees another man possessing something. The possession of wealth is not the cause of happiness in him.

text.pali: Yo saṇhaṁ bhāsamāṇo, piyaṁ vā hadayaṁ sukhaṁ; Hitvā kāmaṁ ca dosaṁ ca, madhuraṁ tassa bhāsitaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The wise man, self-reliant, looks to the end of the journey.

text.pali: Manujassa pamattacārino, taṇhā vaḍḍhati māluvā viya; So plavatī hīrāva babbharū, dukkhāni saṁsāradukkāni tīṇi.
text.en_translator_a: The craving of one given to heedless living grows like a creeper. He runs from life to life like a monkey seeking fruit in the forest.

text.pali: Yaṁ esā sahu dhīraṁ, taṇhāpīḷanaṁ duraccayaṁ; Kāmehi cittaṁ vasaṁ, vappaṁ va āpaṇā care.
text.en_translator_a: Whoever is overcome by this wretched, entangled craving, his sorrows grow like grass after the rains.

text.pali: Yo cetaṁ malaṁ durakkataṁ, taṇhaṁ samūhatā asubhā; Sa ve dukkham anāgataṁ, sabbasaṁyojanaṁ chetvā.
text.en_translator_a: But whoever overcomes this wretched craving, so difficult to overcome, sorrows fall away from him, like water from a lotus leaf.

text.pali: Taṁ kho ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ, yo’dha vejjaṁ pajānāti; Lokasmiṁ pūtimaccherā, saṁkiliṭṭhaṁ pahāy’idha.
text.en_translator_a: This I call a sage: one who knows the meaning of this for himself, who has put away the defilement of craving, who has cut the bond of Māra.

text.pali: Yathāpi mūle anupaddave daḷhe, chinnaṁ na ruṇṇehi phalitaṁ vaḷambati; Evampi khīṇāsavaṁ visaṁyuttaṁ, taṇhāya mūlaṁ pahataṁ tathāgataṁ.
text.en_translator_a: As a tree with root cut down, that does not spring up again even if it is full of leaves and branches, so the Tathāgata, having cut off craving, is not born again.

text.en_translator_a: As a tree with root cut down, that does not spring up again even if it is full of leaves and branches, so the Tathāgata, having cut off craving, is not born again.

text.pali: Cakkhunā saṁvaro sādhu, sādhu sotena saṁvaro; Ghānena saṁvaro sādhu, sādhu jivhāya saṁvaro.
text.en_translator_a: Good is restraint of the eye. Good is restraint of the ear. Good is restraint of the nose. Good is restraint of the tongue.

text.pali: Kāyena saṁvaro sādhu, sādhu vācāya saṁvaro; Manasā saṁvaro sādhu, sādhu sabbattha saṁvaro; Sabbattha saṁvuto bhikkhu, sabba dukkhā pamuccati.
text.en_translator_a: Good is restraint of the body. Good is restraint of speech. Good is restraint of the mind. Restraint everywhere is good. The bhikkhu restrained in all things is freed from all suffering.

text.pali: Hatthasaṁyato pādasaṁyato, vācāsaṁyato saṁyatuttamo; Ajjhattarato samāhito, eko santusito tam āhu bhikkhuṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who controls his hand, he who controls his feet, he who controls his speech, he who is highly controlled, he who delights inwardly, who is concentrated, who walks alone, him they call a bhikkhu.

text.pali: Yo mukhasaṁyato bhikkhu, mantabhāṇī anuddhato; Atthaṁ dhammaṁ ca dīpeti, madhuraṁ tassa bhāsitaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The bhikkhu who keeps his tongue in check, who speaks wisely, who is not proud, who explains the meaning of the Dhamma — sweet is his speech.

text.pali: Dhammārāmo dhammarati, dhammaṁ anuvicintayaṁ; Dhammaṁ anussaraṁ bhikkhu, saddhammā na parihāyati.
text.en_translator_a: The bhikkhu who dwells in the Dhamma, who delights in the Dhamma, who meditates on the Dhamma, who remembers the Dhamma, he does not fall away from the sublime Dhamma.

text.pali: Salābhaṁ nātimaññeyya, nāññesaṁ pihayā care; Aññesaṁ pihayaṁ bhikkhu, samādhiṁ nādhigacchati.
text.en_translator_a: Let him not despise what he receives, nor let him envy others. The bhikkhu who envies others does not attain concentration.

text.pali: Appalābho’pi ce bhikkhu, salābhaṁ nātimaññati; Taṁ ve devā’pi pasaṁsanti, suddhājīviṁ atanditaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: Though he receives but little, if a bhikkhu does not despise what he receives, even the gods praise him, the pure-lived, tireless one.

text.pali: Sabbaso nāmarūpasmiṁ, yassa natthi mamāyitaṁ; Asatā ca na socati, sa ve bhikkhū’ti vuccati.
text.en_translator_a: He who has no attachment to name and form, who does not grieve over what is not, him I call a bhikkhu.

text.pali: Mettāvihārī yo bhikkhu, pasanno buddhasāsane; Adhigacche padaṁ santaṁ, saṁkhārūpasamaṁ sukhaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The bhikkhu who abides in loving-kindness, who is devoted to the Buddha's teaching, attains the peace of Nibbana, the bliss of the cessation of formations.

text.pali: Siñca bhikkhu imaṁ nāvaṁ, sittā te lahum essati; Chetvā rāgaṁ ca dosaṁ ca, tato nibbānam ehisi.
text.en_translator_a: Empty this boat, O bhikkhu! When emptied it will go quickly; having cut off lust and hatred, then you will go to Nibbana.

text.pali: Pañca chinde pañca jahe, pañca c’uttari bhāvaye; Pañca saṅgātigo bhikkhu, oghatiṇṇo’ti vuccati.
text.en_translator_a: Five cut off, five lay down, five further cultivate. The bhikkhu who has gone beyond the five attachments is called 'a crosser of the flood'.

text.pali: Jhāya bhikkhu mā ca pāmado, mā te kāmagṇe bhamassu cittaṁ; Mā lohaguḷaṁ gilī pamatto, mā kandi dukkham idaṁ ti ḍayhamāno.
text.en_translator_a: Meditate, O bhikkhu, do not be heedless. Do not let your mind whirl in the tangles of the senses. Do not swallow an iron ball like a heedless one. Do not burn, crying, 'This is suffering.'

text.pali: Natthi jhānaṁ apaññassa, paññā natthi ajhāyato; Yamhi jhānañca paññā ca, sa ve nibbānasantike.
text.en_translator_a: There is no concentration for him who lacks wisdom, no wisdom for him who lacks concentration. In whom are both concentration and wisdom, he is indeed near unto Nibbana.

text.pali: Suññāgāraṁ paviṭṭhassa, santacittassa bhikkhuno; Amānusī ratī hoti, sammā dhammaṁ vipassato.
text.en_translator_a: For him who enters an empty hut, who has a calm mind, who is heedful, superhuman joy comes to pass, for he sees the Dhamma aright.

text.pali: Yato yato sammasati, khandhānaṁ udayabbayaṁ; Labhati pītipāmojjaṁ, amataṁ taṁ vijānataṁ.
text.en_translator_a: And whenever he sees the rise and fall of the aggregates, he gains joy and rapture; that is the way to the Deathless.

text.pali: Tatrāyam ādi bhavati, idha paññassa bhikkhuno; Indriyagutti santuṭṭhi, pātimokkhe ca saṁvaro; Mitte bhajassu kalyāne, suddh’ājīve atandite.
text.en_translator_a: This is the beginning for a wise bhikkhu: sense-control, contentment, the observance of the Pātimokkha, restraint in the company of good friends, heedfulness.

text.pali: Paṭisanthāravuty’assa, ācārakusalo siyā; Tato pāmojjabahulo, dukkhass’antaṁ karissati.
text.en_translator_a: Let him be hospitable, skilful in conduct, so that good people will delight in him, and the devas will revere him.

text.pali: Vassikā viya pupphāni, maddavāni pamuñcati; Evaṁ rāgaṁ ca dosaṁ ca, vippamuñcetha bhikkhavo.
text.en_translator_a: As the jasmine creeper sheds its withered flowers, even so should bhikkhus shed lust and hatred.

text.pali: Santakāyo santavāco, santavā susamāhito; Vantalokāmiso bhikkhu, upasanto’ti vuccati.
text.en_translator_a: The bhikkhu who is calm in body, in speech, in mind, who is well-composed, who has renounced the allurements of the world, is called 'peaceful'.

text.pali: Attanā coday’attānaṁ, paṭimāse attam attanā; So attagutto satimā, sukhaṁ bhikkhu vihāhisi.
text.en_translator_a: By oneself is evil done; by oneself is one defiled. By oneself is evil left undone; by oneself is one cleansed. Purity and impurity depend on oneself. No one can purify another.

text.pali: Attā hi attano nātho, attā hi attano gati; Tasmā saññamay’attānaṁ, assaṁ bhadraṁ’va vāṇijo.
text.en_translator_a: Thou thyself shouldst be thy refuge; thou thyself shouldst be thy goal. Therefore, O bhikkhu, be thy own refuge, work out thine own salvation with diligence.

text.pali: Pāmojjabahulo bhikkhu, pasanno buddhasāsane; Adhigacche padaṁ santaṁ, saṁkhārūpasamaṁ sukhaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The bhikkhu who is full of joy, who delights in the Buddha's teaching, attains the peace of Nibbana, the bliss of the cessation of formations.

text.pali: Yo have daharo bhikkhu, yuñjati buddhasāsane; So imaṁ lokaṁ pabhāseti, abbhā mutto’va candimā.
text.en_translator_a: Though young in years, a bhikkhu who devotes himself to the Buddha's teaching lights up the world, as the moon freed from clouds shines forth.

text.pali: Chinda sotaṁ parakkamma, kāme panuda brāhmaṇa; Saṁkhārānaṁ khayaṁ ñatvā, akataññū’si brāhmaṇa.
text.en_translator_a: Cut off the stream of craving, O brāhmaṇa, and abandon sense-desires. Having known the destruction of conditioned things, become a knower of the Uncreated.

text.pali: Yadā dvayesu dhammesu, samāhitta cittaṁ te; Atha’ssa sabbe saṁyogā, atthaṁ gacchanti jānato.
text.en_translator_a: When the brāhmaṇa has reached the other shore of the two streams, then all the fetters of the brāhmaṇa cease to exist.

text.pali: Yassa pāraṁ apāraṁ vā, pārāpāraṁ na vijjati; Vītaddaraṁ visaṁyuttaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He for whom there is neither the hither nor the further shore, nor both, him who is free from fear and from fetters, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Jhāyiṁ virajam āsīnaṁ, katakiccaṁ anāsavaṁ; Uttamatthaṁ anuppattaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who is meditative, stainless, and sits in seclusion, who has done his work and is free from the āsavas, who has reached the highest goal, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Divā tapati ādicco, rattiṁ ābhāti candimā; Sannaddho khattiyo tapati, jhāyī tapati brāhmaṇo; Atha sabbam ahorattiṁ, buddho tapati tejasā.
text.en_translator_a: The sun blazes by day, the moon shines by night, the warrior blazes in armor, the brāhmaṇa meditates in samādhi; but all day and night the Buddha shines in glory.

text.pali: Bāhitapāpo’ti brāhmaṇo, samacariyā samaṇo’ti vuccati; Pabbājayaṁ attano malaṁ, tasmā pabbajito’ti vuccati.
text.en_translator_a: He who has destroyed all evil, who is free from moral defilements, who is wise, who has realized the Truth, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Na brāhmaṇassa pahareyya, n’āssa muñcetha brāhmaṇo; Dhī brāhmaṇassa hantāraṁ, tato dhī yassa muñcati.
text.en_translator_a: The brāhmaṇa who does not harm with his body, speech, or mind, who is restrained in these three respects, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Na brāhmaṇass’etad akiñci seyyo, yadā nisedho manaso piyehi; Yato yato hiṁsamano nivattati, tato tato sammatimeva dukkhaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The brāhmaṇa who, having cut off the strap, the thong, the cord, and the bridle, has thrown off the bar, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Yassa kāyena vācāya, manasā natthi dukkaṭaṁ; Saṁvutaṁ tīhi ṭhānehi, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who endures abuse, beating, and imprisonment without anger, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Yamhā dhammaṁ vijāneyya, sammāsambuddhadesitaṁ; Sakkaccaṁ taṁ namasseyya, aggihuttaṁ’va brāhmaṇo.
text.en_translator_a: The brāhmaṇa who is free from anger, who practices austerity, who is virtuous and free from craving, who controls the senses, this body is his last.

text.pali: Na jaṭāhi na gottena, na jaccā hoti brāhmaṇo; Yamhi saccaṁ ca dhammo ca, so sucī so ca brāhmaṇo.
text.en_translator_a: He who does not cling to pleasures, like water does not cling to a lotus leaf, or a mustard seed to the point of an awl, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Kiṁ te jaṭāhi dummedha, kiṁ te ajinasāṭiyā; Abbhantaraṁ te gahanaṁ, bāhiraṁ parimajjasi.
text.en_translator_a: He who knows the end of suffering in this world, who has laid down the burden, who is free from the fetters, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Paṁsukūladharaṁ jantuṁ, kisaṁ dhamanisanthataṁ; Ekaṁ vanasmiṁ jhāyantaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The brāhmaṇa whose wisdom is profound, whose understanding is deep, who knows the right path from the wrong path, who has reached the highest goal, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Na c’āhaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ brūmi, yonijaṁ mattisambhavaṁ; Bhovādi nāma so hoti, sa ce hoti sakiñcano; Akiñcanaṁ anādānaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The brāhmaṇa who has few desires, who is detached from sense-desires, who has renounced all attachments, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Sabbasaṁyojanaṁ chetvā, yo ve na paritassati; Saṅgātigaṁ visaṁyuttaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The brāhmaṇa who has laid down the rod towards all beings, who does not kill or cause to kill, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Chetvā naddhiṁ varattaṁ ca, sandānaṁ sahanukkamaṁ; Ukkhittapaḷighaṁ buddhaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The brāhmaṇa who is friendly among the hostile, peaceful among the violent, who is without attachment among the attached, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Akkosaṁ vadhabandhaṁ ca, aduṭṭho yo titikkhati; Khantībalaṁ balāṇīkaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: From whom lust and hatred, pride and deceit have fallen away like the mustard seed from the point of an awl, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Akkodhanaṁ vatavantaṁ, sīlavantaṁ anussadaṁ; Dantaṁ antimasārīraṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who speaks gentle, instructive, true words, who by his speech offends no one, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Vāripokkharapatt’eva, āragger’iva sāsapo; Yo na limpati kāmesu, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who takes nothing in the world that is not given, whether it be long or short, small or great, fair or foul, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Yo dukkhassa pajānāti, idh’eva khayam attano; Pannabhāraṁ visaṁyuttaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who is free from desires for this world or for the next, who is free from cravings and moral defilements, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Gambhīrapaññaṁ medhāviṁ, maggāmaggassa kovidaṁ; Uttamatthaṁ anuppattaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who is free from craving, who, through knowledge of the Four Noble Truths, is free from doubt, who has realized the Deathless, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Asaṁsaṭṭhaṁ gahaṭṭhehi, anāgārehi c’ūbhayaṁ; Anokasārim appicchaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who, in this world, has gone beyond both good and evil, who is free from sorrow, who is pure, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Nidhāya daṇḍaṁ bhūtesu, tasesu thāvaresu ca; Yo na hanti na ghāteti, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who is pure like a cloudless sky, who is serene and unagitated, in whom craving for existence is extinguished, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Aviruddhaṁ viruddhesu, attadaṇḍesu nibbutaṁ; Sādānesu anādānaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who has crossed the difficult path, the flood, the illusion, the bonds, who has attained the other shore, who is meditative, free from doubt, unattached, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Yassa rāgo ca doso ca, māno makkho ca pātito; Sāsapor’iva āraggā, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who has abandoned sensual pleasures, who has become a homeless one, who has destroyed craving for existence, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Akakkasaṁ viññāpaniṁ, giraṁ saccam udīraye; Yāya n’ābhisaje kañci, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who has abandoned craving, who has become a homeless one, who has destroyed craving for existence, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Yo’dha dīghaṁ va rassaṁ vā, aṇuṁ thūlaṁ subhāsubhaṁ; Loke adinnaṁ nādiyati, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who has abandoned human bonds, who has transcended divine bonds, who is free from all bonds, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Āsā yassa na vijjanti, asmiṁ loke paramhi ca; Nirasāsaṁ visaṁyuttaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who has abandoned delight in existence and non-existence, who has no more attachment, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Yassālayā na vijjanti, aññāya akathaṁkathī; Amatogadhaṁ anuppattaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who, like a tameless horse, is free from pride and attachment, who has conquered the intoxicants, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Yo’dha puññaṁ ca pāpaṁ ca, ubho saṅgaṁ upaccagā; Asokaṁ virajaṁ suddhaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who knows past lives, who sees heaven and hell, who has reached the end of births, who has perfect wisdom, such a sage I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Candaṁ’va vimalaṁ suddhaṁ, vippasannaṁ anāvilaṁ; Nandībhavaparikkhīṇaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who has cut off all fetters, who is free from sorrow, who has destroyed the bond of rebirth, who is detached, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Yo imaṁ paḷipathaṁ duggaṁ, saṁsāraṁ moham accagā; Tiṇṇo pāragato jhāyī, anejo akathaṁkathī; Anupādāya nibbuto, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who has no clinging to aggregates past, future, or present, who is free from attachment, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Yo’dha kāme pahantvāna, anāgāro paribbaje; Kāmabhavaparikkhīṇaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The fearless bull, noble, heroic, who has conquered Māra, who is free from craving, who has cleansed himself of defilements, who knows the Four Noble Truths, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Yo’dha taṇhaṁ pahatvāna, anāgāro paribbaje; Taṇhābhavaparikkhīṇaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who knows past lives, who sees heaven and hell, who has reached the end of births, who has perfect wisdom, such a sage I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Hitvā mānusakaṁ yogaṁ, dibbaṁ yogaṁ upaccagā; Sabbayogavisaṁyuttaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who has cut off all fetters, who is free from sorrow, who has destroyed the bond of rebirth, who is detached, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Hitvā ratiṁ ca aratiṁ ca, sītibhūtaṁ nirūpadhiṁ; Sabbalokābhibhuṁ vīraṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who has no clinging to aggregates past, future, or present, who is free from attachment, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Cutiṁ yo vedi sattānaṁ, upapattiṁ ca sabbaso; Asattaṁ sugataṁ buddhaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The fearless bull, noble, heroic, who has conquered Māra, who is free from craving, who has cleansed himself of defilements, who knows the Four Noble Truths, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Yassa gatiṁ na jānanti, devā gandhabbamānusā; Khīṇāsavaṁ arahantaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who knows past lives, who sees heaven and hell, who has reached the end of births, who has perfect wisdom, such a sage I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Yassa pure ca pacchā ca, majjhe ca natthi kiñcanaṁ; Akiñcanaṁ anādānaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who has cut off all fetters, who is free from sorrow, who has destroyed the bond of rebirth, who is detached, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Usabhaṁ pavaraṁ vīraṁ, mahesiṁ vijitāvinaṁ; Anejaṁ nahātakaṁ buddhaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: He who has no clinging to aggregates past, future, or present, who is free from attachment, him I call a brāhmaṇa.

text.pali: Pubbenivāsaṁ yo vedi, saggāpāyaṁ ca passati; Atho jātikkhayaṁ patto, abhiññāvosito muni; Sabbavositavosānaṁ, tam ahaṁ brūmi brāhmaṇaṁ.
text.en_translator_a: The fearless bull, noble, heroic, who has conquered Māra, who is free from craving, who has cleansed himself of defilements, who knows the Four Noble Truths, him I call a brāhmaṇa.
